channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Mini-antibodies given mighty powers can stave off influenza
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02090-x

Complexes formed from ‘nanobodies’ and an antiviral drug halt infection in its tracks.
item.dc:title: Mini-antibodies given mighty powers can stave off influenza

item.title: A robotic raspberry teaches machines how to pick fruit
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02173-9

This fake raspberry allows researchers to train fruit-picking robots in the lab before field tests.
item.dc:title: A robotic raspberry teaches machines how to pick fruit
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell

item.title: First glimpses inside octopus’s sleeping brains reveals human-like patterns
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02198-0

Neural activity show an ‘active’ sleep stage similar to REM sleep in mammals.
item.dc:title: First glimpses inside octopus’s sleeping brains reveals human-like patterns
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell

item.title: Audio long read: ‘Almost magical’ — chemists can now move single atoms in and out of a molecule’s core
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02081-y

Methods to insert, swap or delete atoms in the backbones of molecules could transform medicinal chemistry.
item.dc:title: Audio long read: ‘Almost magical’ — chemists can now move single atoms in and out of a molecule’s core
item.dc:creator: Mark Peplow
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Giant gravitational waves: why scientists are so excited
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02203-6

Astrophysicists describe what galaxy-wide gravitational waves could mean for our understanding of black holes and the history of the cosmos.
item.dc:title: Giant gravitational waves: why scientists are so excited
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Euclid launch: dark-energy mapper poised to probe cosmic mysteries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02194-4

The European craft could help to investigate why the Universe’s expansion is accelerating, along with other cosmic questions.
item.dc:title: Euclid launch: dark-energy mapper poised to probe cosmic mysteries
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Tasmanian devil cancer vaccine approved for testing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02124-4

The vaccine was inspired by COVID jabs, but if it is approved, it will be delivered in edible bait.
item.dc:title: Tasmanian devil cancer vaccine approved for testing
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: These six distant galaxies captured by JWST are wowing astronomers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02157-9

See researchers’ favourites from a survey of the deep Universe by the James Webb Space Telescope.
item.dc:title: These six distant galaxies captured by JWST are wowing astronomers
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: How to train early-career scientists to weather failure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02168-6

Workshops and training programmes tackle failure and how to recover from it.
item.dc:title: How to train early-career scientists to weather failure
item.dc:creator: Laurie Udesky

item.title: Australia to prescribe MDMA and psilocybin for PTSD and depression in world first
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02093-8

Decision to make the previously illicit drugs available is dogged by suggestions the decision was rushed.
item.dc:title: Australia to prescribe MDMA and psilocybin for PTSD and depression in world first
item.dc:creator: Rich Haridy

item.title: Quantum metric-induced nonlinear transport in a topological antiferromagnet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06363-3

Quantum metric-induced nonlinear transport in a topological antiferromagnet
item.dc:title: Quantum metric-induced nonlinear transport in a topological antiferromagnet

item.title: Monster gravitational waves spotted for first time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02167-7

Using beacon stars called pulsars, a decades-long effort has found space-time ripples that are light years wide.
item.dc:title: Monster gravitational waves spotted for first time
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Postdoctoral researchers warn NIH that cost-of-living pressures are gutting the workforce
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02202-7

Pay and benefits top the list of concerns identified by US working group.
item.dc:title: Postdoctoral researchers warn NIH that cost-of-living pressures are gutting the workforce
item.dc:creator: Virginia Gewin

item.title: El Niño is here — how bad will it be?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02122-6

The strong climate pattern could push global temperatures to record highs.
item.dc:title: El Niño is here — how bad will it be?
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: US to end race-based university admissions: what now for diversity in science?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01900-6

Researchers talk to Nature about how halting race-conscious admissions will affect STEM employment, university applications and more.
item.dc:title: US to end race-based university admissions: what now for diversity in science?
item.dc:creator: Helen Santoro

item.title: Foldseek gives AlphaFold protein database a rapid search tool
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02205-4

The structural search program makes finding proteins with similar 3D shapes easy.
item.dc:title: Foldseek gives AlphaFold protein database a rapid search tool
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hutson

item.title: John Bannister Goodenough, battery pioneer (1922–2023)
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02152-0

Materials scientist and Nobel laureate who invented the rechargeable lithium batteries used in electric cars and phones.
item.dc:title: John Bannister Goodenough, battery pioneer (1922–2023)
item.dc:creator: Bill David
Michael Thackeray

item.title: New COVID jabs are coming — who should get them?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02188-2

Countries rolling out updated vaccines weigh up whether to restrict them to high-risk individuals.
item.dc:title: New COVID jabs are coming — who should get them?
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Robots need better batteries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02170-y

As mobile machines travel farther from the grid, they’ll need lightweight and efficient power sources.
item.dc:title: Robots need better batteries
item.dc:creator: Jeff Hecht

item.title: Promising tuberculosis vaccine gets US$550-million shot in the arm
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02171-x

The candidate is moving to long-awaited phase III trials — if successful, it would be the first new jab against the disease in more than 100 years.
item.dc:title: Promising tuberculosis vaccine gets US$550-million shot in the arm
item.dc:creator: Lilly Tozer

item.title: Fanzor is a eukaryotic programmable RNA-guided endonuclease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06356-2

Fanzor is a eukaryotic programmable RNA-guided endonuclease
item.dc:title: Fanzor is a eukaryotic programmable RNA-guided endonuclease

item.title: Femtosecond proton transfer in urea solutions probed by X-ray spectroscopy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06182-6

The potential of water-window X-ray absorption spectroscopy for disentangling individual aspects of the respective electronic and structural dynamics in ultrafast non-adiabatic dynamics of molecular systems in a liquid environment is established.
item.dc:title: Femtosecond proton transfer in urea solutions probed by X-ray spectroscopy

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06345-5

Detection of stellar light from quasar host galaxies at redshifts above 6
item.dc:title: Detection of stellar light from quasar host galaxies at redshifts above 6

item.title: Battling a health crisis in the Amazon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02055-0

Scientists are racing to control malaria in northern Brazil where the disease is playing a major part in the current health emergency threatening the region’s Indigenous people.
item.dc:title: Battling a health crisis in the Amazon

item.title: Super-cooling lasers could help to reveal celestial chemistry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02088-5

A trick to chill molecular ions to below the temperature of liquid helium might be useful for understanding reactions at Saturn’s moon Titan.
item.dc:title: Super-cooling lasers could help to reveal celestial chemistry

item.title: Do octopuses dream? Neural activity resembles human sleep stages
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02169-5

Brain probes reveal complexities of octopus sleep, and a hormone that could help make calorie-restricted diets more effective.
item.dc:title: Do octopuses dream? Neural activity resembles human sleep stages
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Shamini Bundell

item.title: The challenges facing scientists in the elimination of malaria
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02047-0

The world now has a malaria vaccine, but it won’t be enough to wipe out the parasitic disease
item.dc:title: The challenges facing scientists in the elimination of malaria
item.dc:creator: Richard Hodson

item.title: The importance of trait selection in ecology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06148-8

The importance of trait selection in ecology
item.dc:title: The importance of trait selection in ecology

item.title: Photocatalytic phosphine-mediated water activation for radical hydrogenation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06141-1

Using a photocatalytic phosphine-mediated radical process under mild conditions enables direct hydrogen atom transfer to closed-shell π systems for activation of water.
item.dc:title: Photocatalytic phosphine-mediated water activation for radical hydrogenation
item.dc:creator: Jingjing Zhang
Christian Mück-Lichtenfeld
Armido Studer

item.title: Reply to: The importance of trait selection in ecology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06149-7

Reply to: The importance of trait selection in ecology
item.dc:title: Reply to: The importance of trait selection in ecology

item.title: Natural short-lived halogens exert an indirect cooling effect on climate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06119-z

Short-lived halogens have a substantial indirect cooling effect on climate and this cooling effect has increased since pre-industrial times owing to anthropogenic amplification of natural halogen emissions.
item.dc:title: Natural short-lived halogens exert an indirect cooling effect on climate
item.dc:creator: Alfonso Saiz-Lopez
Rafael P. Fernandez

item.title: Frequency–angular resolving LiDAR using chip-scale acousto-optic beam steering
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06201-6

Three-dimensional imaging using a frequency–angular resolving and frequency-modulated continuous-wave LiDAR enabled by a chip-scale acousto-optic beam-steering device has been demonstrated, with the simplicity and low cost of the device making this a promising technology.
item.dc:title: Frequency–angular resolving LiDAR using chip-scale acousto-optic beam steering
item.dc:creator: Bingzhao Li
Qixuan Lin
Mo Li

item.title: Continuous carbon capture in an electrochemical solid-electrolyte reactor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06060-1

By combining O2/H2O redox electrolysis with a modular solid-electrolyte reactor, a design for continuous electrochemical carbon capture showing high capture rates, high Faradaic efficiencies and low energy consumption is demonstrated.
item.dc:title: Continuous carbon capture in an electrochemical solid-electrolyte reactor
item.dc:creator: Peng Zhu

Haotian Wang

item.title: GDF15 promotes weight loss by enhancing energy expenditure in muscle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06249-4

GDF15 treatment in mice counteracts compensatory reductions in energy expenditure, resulting in greater weight loss and reductions in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease compared to caloric restriction alone.
item.dc:title: GDF15 promotes weight loss by enhancing energy expenditure in muscle

item.title: Continuous synthesis of E. coli genome sections and Mb-scale human DNA assembly
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06268-1

BAC stepwise insertion synthesis (BASIS) can be used to build synthetic genomes for diverse organisms, and continuous genome synthesis (CGS) enables the rapid synthesis of entire Escherichia coli genomes from functional designs.
item.dc:title: Continuous synthesis of E. coli genome sections and Mb-scale human DNA assembly
item.dc:creator: Jérôme F. Zürcher

Jason W. Chin

item.title: Reprogramming tumour-associated macrophages to outcompete cancer cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06256-5

In a mouse model of breast cancer, a low-protein diet induces engulfment activities and mTORC1 signalling in tumour-associated macrophages to suppress engulfment-dependent mTORC1 signalling in MYC-overexpressing cancer cells through cell competition, serving as an innate immune defence mechanism to slow tumour growth.
item.dc:title: Reprogramming tumour-associated macrophages to outcompete cancer cells

item.title: Pair density wave state in a monolayer high-Tc iron-based superconductor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06072-x

The primary pair density wave state has been discovered in a monolayer iron-based high-Tc superconductor, providing a platform to study the interplay between the correlated electronic states and unconventional Cooper pairing in high-Tc superconductors.
item.dc:title: Pair density wave state in a monolayer high-Tc iron-based superconductor
item.dc:creator: Yanzhao Liu
Tianheng Wei
Guanyang He
Yi Zhang
Ziqiang Wang
Jian Wang

item.title: The dynamics of pattern matching in camouflaging cuttlefish
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06259-2

The cuttlefish Sepia officinalis uses high-dimensional skin patterns for camouflage, and the pattern matching process is not stereotyped—each search meanders through skin-pattern space, decelerating and accelerating repeatedly before stabilizing.
item.dc:title: The dynamics of pattern matching in camouflaging cuttlefish
item.dc:creator: Theodosia Woo
Xitong Liang
Dominic A. Evans
Olivier Fernandez
Friedrich Kretschmer
Sam Reiter
Gilles Laurent

item.title: Cancer aneuploidies are shaped primarily by effects on tumour fitness
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06266-3

A study reports the development of an algorithm, BISCUT, that detects genomic loci under selective pressure by relying on the distribution of breakpoints across chromosome arms, and uses it to explore how aneuploidies affect tumorigenesis.
item.dc:title: Cancer aneuploidies are shaped primarily by effects on tumour fitness
item.dc:creator: Juliann Shih
Shahab Sarmashghi

item.title: Detection of a pair density wave state in UTe<sub>2</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05919-7

A spin-triplet pair density wave is discovered in the candidate topological superconductor UTe2 using superconductive scanning tunnelling microscopy tips.
item.dc:title: Detection of a pair density wave state in UTe<sub>2</sub>
item.dc:creator: Qiangqiang Gu

item.title: Smectic pair-density-wave order in EuRbFe<sub>4</sub>As<sub>4</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06103-7

Measurements show that smectic pair-density-wave order exists in the magnetic iron pnictide superconductor EuRbFe4As4 and that the pair-density-wave state is a primary, zero-field superconducting state in this compound.
item.dc:title: Smectic pair-density-wave order in EuRbFe<sub>4</sub>As<sub>4</sub>

Abhay N. Pasupathy
Kazuhiro Fujita

item.title: BTN3A3 evasion promotes the zoonotic potential of influenza A viruses
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06261-8

A protein that evolved in primates, BTN3A3, is expressed in human airways and shows antiviral activity against avian IAVs but not against human IAVs.
item.dc:title: BTN3A3 evasion promotes the zoonotic potential of influenza A viruses
item.dc:creator: Rute Maria Pinto

item.title: Galaxies in voids assemble their stars slowly
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06109-1

We show that void galaxies have had slower star formation histories than galaxies in denser large-scale environments and find two main types of star formation history in all environments.
item.dc:title: Galaxies in voids assemble their stars slowly

item.title: A close-in giant planet escapes engulfment by its star
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06029-0

The giant planet 8 Ursae Minoris b seems to have avoided engulfment by its giant host star through a stellar merger that either affected the evolution of the host star or produced 8 Ursae Minoris b as a second-generation planet.
item.dc:title: A close-in giant planet escapes engulfment by its star

Dakotah Tyler
Judah Van Zandt
Lauren M. Weiss

item.title: A spatially resolved single-cell genomic atlas of the adult human breast
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06252-9

The Human Breast Cell Atlas identifies 12 major breast cell types and 58 biological cell states, revealing abundant pericyte, endothelial and immune cell populations, and highly diverse luminal epithelial cell states.
item.dc:title: A spatially resolved single-cell genomic atlas of the adult human breast
item.dc:creator: Tapsi Kumar
Kevin Nee
Runmin Wei

Nicholas Navin

item.title: A warming-induced reduction in snow fraction amplifies rainfall extremes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06092-7

The recent and projected future increase in rainfall extremes in high-elevation areas of the Northern Hemisphere is due to a warming-induced shift from snow to rain.
item.dc:title: A warming-induced reduction in snow fraction amplifies rainfall extremes
item.dc:creator: Mohammed Ombadi
Mark D. Risser
Alan M. Rhoades
Charuleka Varadharajan

item.title: Remote neuronal activity drives glioma progression through SEMA4F
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06267-2

Callosal projection neurons located in the hemisphere contralateral to primary glioblastoma promote progression and widespread infiltration, and screening of axon guidance genes identified SEMA4F as a key regulator of tumourigenesis and activity-dependent progression.
item.dc:title: Remote neuronal activity drives glioma progression through SEMA4F
item.dc:creator: Emmet Huang-Hobbs
Yi-Ting Cheng
Yeunjung Ko
Estefania Luna-Figueroa
Brittney Lozzi
Kathryn R. Taylor
Malcolm McDonald
Peihao He
Hsiao-Chi Chen
Yuhui Yang
Ehson Maleki
Zhung-Fu Lee
Sanjana Murali
Michael R. Williamson
Dongjoo Choi

Michelle Monje
Jeffrey L. Noebels
Akdes Serin Harmanci
Ganesh Rao
Benjamin Deneen

item.title: Wake-like skin patterning and neural activity during octopus sleep
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06203-4

Octopuses possess a distinct active sleep stage, with behavioural and neural correlates resembling vertebrate REM sleep, which may represent convergent features of complex cognition.
item.dc:title: Wake-like skin patterning and neural activity during octopus sleep
item.dc:creator: Aditi Pophale
Kazumichi Shimizu
Tomoyuki Mano
Teresa L. Iglesias
Kerry Martin
Makoto Hiroi
Keishu Asada
Paulette García Andaluz
Thi Thu Van Dinh
Leenoy Meshulam
Sam Reiter

item.title: A well-oxygenated eastern tropical Pacific during the warm Miocene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06104-6

Analysis of palaeoceanographic proxies sensitive to oxygen-deficient zone extent and intensity show that the eastern tropical Pacific was well oxygenated during the warm Miocene, agreeing with model simulations that suggest that the recent deoxygenation trend may eventually reverse.
item.dc:title: A well-oxygenated eastern tropical Pacific during the warm Miocene
item.dc:creator: Anya V. Hess
Alexandra Auderset
Yair Rosenthal
Kenneth G. Miller
Xiaoli Zhou
Daniel M. Sigman
Alfredo Martínez-García

item.title: Magnetic-field-sensitive charge density waves in the superconductor UTe<sub>2</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06005-8

A study using scanning tunnelling microscopy reveals a charge-density-wave state that is sensitive to magnetic fields and strongly intertwined with superconductivity in the heavy-fermion triplet superconductor UTe2.
item.dc:title: Magnetic-field-sensitive charge density waves in the superconductor UTe<sub>2</sub>
item.dc:creator: Anuva Aishwarya
Julian May-Mann
Arjun Raghavan
Laimei Nie
Marisa Romanelli
Sheng Ran
Shanta R. Saha
Johnpierre Paglione
Nicholas P. Butch
Eduardo Fradkin
Vidya Madhavan

item.title: Locus for severity implicates CNS resilience in progression of multiple sclerosis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06250-x

A genome-wide association study including 22,389 cases of multiple sclerosis finds an association with disease progression at the DYSF–ZNF638 and DNM3–PIGC loci and identifies a potential of higher educational attainment in slowing disease progression.
item.dc:title: Locus for severity implicates CNS resilience in progression of multiple sclerosis

item.title: Phase separation of FSP1 promotes ferroptosis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06255-6

An inhibitor of the ferroptosis-suppressing FSP1 induces phase separation of FSP1, thereby impairing its function and reducing tumour growth.
item.dc:title: Phase separation of FSP1 promotes ferroptosis
item.dc:creator: Toshitaka Nakamura
Clara Hipp
André Santos Dias Mourão
Jan Borggräfe
Maceler Aldrovandi
Bernhard Henkelmann

David Emler
Bettina Proneth
Michael Sattler

item.title: Circuit coordination of opposing neuropeptide and neurotransmitter signals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06246-7

CRISPR–Cas9 mutagenesis studies in mice demonstrate co-release of a neurotransmitter and a neuropeptide with opposing signals that stimulate the ventral tegmental area dopamine system through coordinated actions on different cells at different time scales.
item.dc:title: Circuit coordination of opposing neuropeptide and neurotransmitter signals
item.dc:creator: Marta E. Soden
Joshua X. Yee
Larry S. Zweifel

item.title: Gut microbial fatty acid isomerization modulates intraepithelial T cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06265-4

A diet–microorganism pathway involving conjugated linoleic acid, interleukin-18, intraepithelial lymphocytes and the transcription factor hepatocyte nuclear factor  4γ modulates the host mucosal immune system.
item.dc:title: Gut microbial fatty acid isomerization modulates intraepithelial T cells
item.dc:creator: Xinyang Song
Haohao Zhang
Yanbo Zhang
Byoungsook Goh
Bin Bao
Suelen S. Mello

Meng Wu
Fangfang Qu
Qiangzong Yin
Michael S. Gilmore
Sungwhan F. Oh
Dennis L. Kasper

item.title: Daily briefing: Answers emerge about long COVID recovery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02190-8

What the evidence says about recovering from long COVID. Plus, coronaviruses found in British bats and researchers discover a palm that grows its fruit and flowers underground.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Answers emerge about long COVID recovery
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Malaria’s modelling problem
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02054-1

Southern Africa wants to eliminate the disease by 2030, but predicting where and when the disease will strike remains a challenge.
item.dc:title: Malaria’s modelling problem
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: No drug for COVID: ‘the most successful failure in my life’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02125-3

Laura Walker co-founded a spin-off company, but she moved to big pharma after the therapy the firm had been testing came to nothing. She explains why.
item.dc:title: No drug for COVID: ‘the most successful failure in my life’
item.dc:creator: Rachel Brazil

item.title: Bullying in academia: why it happens and how to stop it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02172-w

Lab bullies cause lasting damage to both individuals and institutions, say Morteza Mahmoudi and Chris Jackson.
item.dc:title: Bullying in academia: why it happens and how to stop it
item.dc:creator: Adam Levy

item.title: Can malaria researchers slow the spread of drug resistance?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02052-3

Concerns that artemisinin combination treatments are losing their effectiveness against Plasmodium parasites have set scientists looking for alternatives.
item.dc:title: Can malaria researchers slow the spread of drug resistance?
item.dc:creator: T. V. Padma

item.title: Natural halogen-containing compounds cool the climate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02040-7

Simulations using a model of the Earth system have shed light on the role of short-lived halogen-containing gases in climate change. The findings suggest that these gases should now be included in all Earth-system models.
item.dc:title: Natural halogen-containing compounds cool the climate
item.dc:creator: Laura Revell

item.title: Energy burn in muscle boosted by a hormonal signalling axis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01790-8

Restricting dietary calories leads to weight loss, but with time these effects diminish because the body’s metabolism slows down. A hormone called GDF15 is now shown to maintain weight loss during dieting by promoting energy expenditure through the activation of pathways that affect calcium levels in skeletal muscle.
item.dc:title: Energy burn in muscle boosted by a hormonal signalling axis

item.title: Ancient-DNA researcher fired for ‘serious misconduct’ lands new role
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02147-x

Former co-workers have expressed shock that Charles Sturt University in southeastern Australia has appointed Alan Cooper to its faculty
item.dc:title: Ancient-DNA researcher fired for ‘serious misconduct’ lands new role
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: The next frontier for malaria vaccination
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02048-z

Hot on the heels of the first approved vaccine for malaria, researchers are racing to develop even better shots that tackle the parasite at every stage of its life cycle.
item.dc:title: The next frontier for malaria vaccination
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Willyard

item.title: Memory Day report
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02067-w

Bringing history to life.
item.dc:title: Memory Day report
item.dc:creator: Dominic Bock

item.title: Malaria: highlights from research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02050-5

A mosquito hibernation mystery solved, parasites grown in dishes for the first time, and other studies and trials.
item.dc:title: Malaria: highlights from research
item.dc:creator: Laura Vargas-Parada

item.title: Global warming intensifies rainfall in mountainous regions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02001-0

As the climate warms, the amount of atmospheric water vapour increases and the type of precipitation shifts towards more rain and less snow. These two mechanisms amplify the intensity of rainfall extremes in high-elevation regions by 15% per degree Celsius of warming, approximately double the previously reported rate.
item.dc:title: Global warming intensifies rainfall in mountainous regions

item.title: A decades-long decline in extreme poverty has gone into reverse — here’s how to fix things
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02098-3

Factors ranging from COVID-19 to Russia’s war in Ukraine are increasing extreme poverty. Finding effective solutions starts with agreeing on how to measure what poverty means.
item.dc:title: A decades-long decline in extreme poverty has gone into reverse — here’s how to fix things

item.title: In search of a vaccine for Plasmodium vivax malaria
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02053-2

Vaccinologist Arturo Reyes-Sandoval explains how researchers are edging closer to a much-needed vaccine.
item.dc:title: In search of a vaccine for Plasmodium vivax malaria
item.dc:creator: Laura Vargas-Parada

item.title: Widespread pair density waves spark superconductor search
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01996-w

Periodic waves of changing electron density are linked to the ability of some materials to conduct electricity without resistance. Four studies reveal that such waves could emerge in more materials than expected.
item.dc:title: Widespread pair density waves spark superconductor search
item.dc:creator: Hui Chen
Hong-Jun Gao

item.title: A human protein that holds bird flu viruses at bay
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01942-w

Avian influenza A viruses that can cross the species barrier could cause the next pandemic. Mutations in the viral genome have now been found that can overcome a newly discovered antiviral protein, BTN3A3, in human cells.
item.dc:title: A human protein that holds bird flu viruses at bay
item.dc:creator: Laura Graf
Peter Staeheli

item.title: Monoclonal antibodies show promise for malaria prevention
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02049-y

Immunologist Robert Seder and malaria epidemiologist Kassoum Kayentao talk to Nature about their work and how they think the parasitic disease could be controlled in the future.
item.dc:title: Monoclonal antibodies show promise for malaria prevention
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Willyard

item.title: Start-ups are adding antacids to the ocean to slow global warming. Will it work?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02032-7

A New York experiment is part of a commercial race to develop ocean-based technologies to extract carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
item.dc:title: Start-ups are adding antacids to the ocean to slow global warming. Will it work?
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: How genetically modified mosquitoes could eradicate malaria
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02051-4

Gene-drive technology that can spread antimalarial modifications throughout mosquito populations is maturing, but there are questions to answer before it can be used in the wild.
item.dc:title: How genetically modified mosquitoes could eradicate malaria
item.dc:creator: Sam Jones
